ygData.subject: RE: [archive-crawler] Incremental Crawling
ygData.msgSnippet: The ARFrontier differs from the regular one in that it reschedules URIs after they are processed, instead of discarding them. The scheduling of URIs is ordered

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The ARFrontier differs from the regular one in that it reschedules URIs
aft=
er they are processed, instead of discarding them. The scheduling of URIs
i=
s ordered by their assigned 'time of next fetch'.  For newly discovered
URI=
s, this time is set as 'now.'  There is a processor called the
WaitEvaluato=
r that should be used with the ARFrontier. It will impose a wait
time for t=
he URIs before they can be crawled again. So the ARFrontier itself
simply i=
ssues its URIs as they become available. Responsibility for deciding
when t=
hey should be processed is delegated to the processors making it easy
to ch=
ange the revisiting logic.
 
- Kris

-----Original Message-----
From: archi=
ve-crawler@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com] On Beha=
lf Of Dennis Hotson
Sent: 13. september 2005 00:08
To: archive-crawler@yaho=
ogroups.com
Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Incremental Crawling


On Mon, 2=
005-09-12 at 11:49 -0700, stack wrote:

> > I've written a proof of concept=
 filter class that does this (well
> > actually, it's not quite working yet=
).
> 
> How does your filter work?

The filter I wrote manually does a HEAD=
 request and then checks the date
against the database I'm storing pages in=
.. if the page needs updating
then the filter passes.. otherwise the filter=
 will fail and the url gets
skipped.
When I get time, I'll finish it off an=
d test to see if it actually
works.. :P

I just had a look at the AdaptiveR=
evisitingFrontier... from my
understanding it will behave like a regular fr=
ontier except that it
checks whether content needs updating first. After ge=
tting the content
it will then wait a specified time before crawling it aga=
in. Is this
correct?
How does it check if the page needs updating? I'm usin=
g Heritrix to
insert pages into a TeraText database (http://www.teratext.co=
m.au) and
I've written a custom Writer/Processor module to insert the pages=
 into
the database (as opposed to the default ARCWriter module).

Will this=
 frontier still work with my setup?

Thanks very much for you help. :)
